intro: Acanthella conferta, commonly known as the woolly acanthella, is a species of flowering plant native to South Africa. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its dense, woolly foliage that gives it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pale blue or purple in color. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its unique appearance and ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthella conferta is primarily native to the eastern coast of Australia, specifically from Queensland to New South Wales. It is commonly found in coastal heathlands and sand dunes. This plant thrives in sandy soils and is often associated with coastal ecosystems. It is well adapted to the salty and windy conditions of the coastal environment. Acanthella conferta plays an important role in stabilizing dunes and providing habitat for native wildlife.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthella conferta was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was first recorded in the 1970s and has since spread throughout the North Island.
